If violations of the Compulsory School Attendance Law continue, upon the second and subsequent convictions, the parent, guardian or custodian of the student who knowingly allows the student to continue to violate the Compulsory School Attendance Law shall be guilty of a Class A offense and shall be subject to a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1000.00) or imprisonment for a definite term not to exceed three hundred sixty-five days (365) or both.

section.heading: Failure to Submit to Treatment for a Contagious Disease.

para.text: A person shall be guilty of failure to submit to treatment for a contagious disease if that person, knowing that he/she is infected with a sexually transmitted disease, including HIV/AIDS, active tuberculosis, or any other contagious disease and who willfully exposes another to the disease, in a place other than a medical facility.

The Court, upon finding reasonable cause to believe that the person has any of the diseases, may order the person to be examined. If, upon examination, the person is found to be infected with a contagious disease, the Court may order the person to submit to medical treatment as prescribed by a competent medical authority.
Failure to submit to treatment for a contagious disease is a Class B offense. The Court, in its discretion, may suspend such sentence if offender agrees to medical treatment.
A person is guilty of false alarms if he/she knowingly:
Cause a false fire alarm or alarm of other emergency to be transmitted to or within any organization, official or volunteer, for dealing with emergencies involving danger to life or property; or
Gives false information to any law enforcement officer with purpose to implicate another in an offense; or
Reports to law enforcement authorities an offense or other incident within their concern knowing or believing that it did not occur; or
Pretends to furnish law enforcement authorities with information relating to an offense or incident when he/she knows he/she has no information relating to such an offense or incident; or
Gives a false name or address to a law enforcement officer in the lawful discharge of his/her official duties.
False alarms are a Class B offense.

A person shall be guilty of false imprisonment if that person intentionally confines or restrains another person without his/her consent and with the knowledge that he/she has no lawful authority to do so.
False imprisonment is a Class A offense. At the discretion of the Court, such offenders may be required to pay restitution to the victim and/or the victim's family.

A person shall be guilty of forgery if that person falsely makes or alters any signature to, or any part of, any writing purporting to have any legal effect with the intent to injure or defraud another.
Forgery is a Class A offense. The Court may order such offender to pay restitution to the victim.

A person shall be guilty of fraud if that person willfully misrepresents or by deceit, or by false interpretation, or by the use of false weights or measures, obtains any money or takes anything of value from another.
Fraud is a Class B offense. The Court may order such offender to pay restitution to the victim.

section.heading: Glue, Aerosol Spray; Abuse or Possession for Abuse.

para.text: A person shall be guilty of abuse or possession with intent to abuse glue and/or aerosol spray if:

That person intentionally smells, sniffs or inhales the fumes or vapors from a glue, aerosol spray product or other chemical substance for purpose of causing a condition of, or inducing, symptoms of intoxication, elation, dizziness, excitement, irrational behavior, exhilaration, or dulling of the senses, or for the purpose of in any manner changing, distorting, or disturbing the audio, visual or mental process.
No person shall intentionally possess glue, aerosol spray product(s), and/or any other chemical substance for the illegal purpose set forth on this section.
Glue, aerosol spray; abuse or possession for abuse is a Class B offense.

Harassment consists of knowingly pursuing a pattern of conduct that is intended to annoy, seriously alarm or terrorize another person that serves no lawful purpose. The conduct must be such that it would cause a reasonable person to suffer substantial emotional distress.
Harassment is a Class C offense.

section.heading: Harboring or Aiding a Criminal Offender.

para.text: A person shall be guilty of harboring or aiding a criminal offender if any person, knowingly conceals any criminal offender or gives such offender any other aid with knowledge that a criminal offender has committed a crime, with the intent that the criminal offender escape or avoid arrest, trial, conviction, or punishment.
Harboring or aiding a criminal offender is a Class B offense.

section.heading: Impersonating a Law Enforcement Officer or Tribal Officer.

para.text: A person shall be guilty of impersonating a law enforcement officer or tribal officer if that person:
Without due authority exercises or attempts to exercise the functions of any law enforcement officer or tribal officer; or
Falsely assumes or pretends to be a law enforcement officer with intent to deceive another person.
Impersonating a law enforcement officer or tribal officer is a Class A offense.
A person shall be guilty of improper control of a fire if that person:

By setting a fire or causing or procuring a fire to be set to any flammable vegetation or forest material, growing or being on lands of another person and without permission of the owner thereof and without proper permit issued by the Pueblo of Picuris Forest and Wildland Fire Department;
By allowing fire to escape or spread from the control of the person having charge thereof without using reasonable and proper precaution to prevent such fire from escaping or spreading;

By burning any flammable vegetation or forest material, whether upon his/her own land or that of another person, without using proper and reasonable precaution at all times to prevent the escape of such fire;
By leaving any campfire burning and unattended;

By causing a fire to be started in any flammable vegetation or forest material, growing or being upon the lands of another person, by means of any lighted cigar, cigarette, match or other manner and leaving such fire unexhausted;

Improper control of a fire is a Class A offense. The Court may order the offender to pay restitution for damages and forfeit those personal items that were used to start the fire and any other possessions that may be sold to recover costs.
A person shall be guilty of incest if that person knowingly intermarries or has sexual intercourse with a person within the following degrees of blood relationship:
Parents and children; including grandparents and grandchildren of every degree;
Brothers and sisters of the half, as well as of the whole blood;
Uncles and nieces/nephews; aunts and nephews/nieces.
Incest is a Class A offense.
A person shall be guilty of indecent exposure if that person knowingly and intentionally exposes his/her primary genital area to public view.
Indecent exposure is a Class B offense.

section.heading: Interference with Members of Staff, Public Officials or the General Public; Trespass; or Damage to Property.

para.text: A person shall be guilty of interference with members of staff, public official or the general public; trespass; or damage to property if such person shall be in any building or facility or property owned, operated or controlled by the Pueblo, state or federal government, willfully deny to staff, public officials or the general public:
Lawful freedom of movement within the building or facility or the land on which it is situated;
Lawful use of the building or facility or the land on which it is situated;
The right of lawful entry and exit to the building or facility or the land on which it is situated; or

Willfully refuses or fails to leave the said property when requested to do so by a lawful custodian of the building, facility or property if the person is committing, threatens to commit or incites others to commit any act which would disrupt, impair, interfere with or obstruct the lawful mission, processes, procedures, and/or functions of the property, building or facility.
Interference with members of staff, public officials, or the general public; trespass; or damage to property is a Class C offense.

A person shall be guilty of issuing a worthless check if that person issues in exchange for anything of value, with the intent to defraud, any check, draft, or order for payment of money upon any bank or other depository, for the payment of such check, draft, or order in full upon its presentation.
Issuing a worthless check is a Class B offense. The Court may order such offender to pay restitution to the victim.
A person shall be guilty of kidnapping if that person unlawfully takes, restrains, or confines a person, by force or deception, with the intent that the victim:
Be held for ransom;
As a hostage or shield and confined against his/her will; or
Be held to service against the victim's will.
Kidnapping is a Class A offense. Upon conviction thereof, at the discretion of the Court, such offenders may be required to pay restitution to the victim and/or the victim's family.

A person shall be guilty of larceny if that person takes or exercises unlawful control over movable property not his/her own, without the permission of the owner. Upon conviction thereof, shall be sentenced as follows:
For property valued fifty dollars ($50) or less, shall be a Class C offense.
For property valued over fifty dollars ($50) but not more than five hundred dollars ($500), shall be a Class B offense; or
For property valued over five hundred dollars ($500), shall be a Class A offense.
The Court may order such offender to pay restitution to the owner of the stolen property.

A person shall be guilty of libel if that person, with the intent to harm the reputation of another, willfully writes, prints, publishes, sells or circulates any falsehood or malicious statement, knowing the same to be untrue, or which exposes another to hatred, contempt, ridicule degradation or disgrace.
Libel is a Class C offense. The Court may require such offenders to make a public retraction of the written falsehood.
A person shall be guilty of littering if that person knowingly discards refuse:

On public property in any manner other than by placing the refuse in a receptacle provided for the purpose by the responsible governmental authorities, or otherwise in accordance with lawful direction; or
On private property not owned or lawfully occupied or controlled by the person, except with the consent of the owner, lessee or occupant thereof.

Littering is a Class B offense. The Court may to the extent permitted by law, as a condition to suspension of any other penalty provided by law, require the offender to pick up and remove from any public place or any private property any litter deposited thereon. The Court may also require restitution for any and all damages caused by debris, from vehicles transporting substances not securely and appropriately covered which litter the environment.
A person is guilty of livestock offense if he/she:
Knowingly or recklessly refuses or fails to mark or brand his/her livestock when such is required in the interest of livestock identification or directed by Pueblo or government officials; or
Alters, obliterates, or removes a brand or mark, or misbrands or mismarks livestock with a purpose to deceive another for any reason; or
Knowingly permits his/her livestock to graze or trespass on the property of another or of the Pueblo without permission to do so or in excess of permitted time or amount; or
Knowingly refuses to sell, dispose, or otherwise remove sick or otherwise infectious livestock from common grazing areas or areas where there is a substantial danger of infecting other livestock; or
Knowingly fails to treat or dispose of a sick animal where there is a substantial danger of infecting other animals; or
Fails to dip, inoculate or otherwise treat livestock in the manner which the Tribal Council or its designated representative shall direct; or
Makes a false report of livestock owned; or
Purposely obstructs or interferes with a livestock roundup.

Except in cases in which the owner or person having custody of livestock is believed to be in violation of this section cannot be found after reasonable search, no conviction shall be found for Subsections (1), (2), (3), (4) or (5) set forth above, unless the owner or person having custody of the livestock involved is given forty-eight (48) hours written notice of his/her alleged violation and he/she has not, after such period of notice, remedied the alleged violation.

Livestock found to be in violation of this section may be impounded at the time an arrest is made, and may be impounded without prior notice to the owner if a Court so orders upon receipt of evidence that such animals seriously threaten the property of the Tribe or another or the health of other livestock within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris, and that immediate action is necessary to protect such interests from serious harm. A reasonable fee for the care of such animals may be collected prior to their release.
Livestock offense is a Class C offense.
A person shall be guilty of maintaining a public nuisance if that person knowingly;
Acts in such a manner to place another person in fear of their health, safety, comfort; or
Interferes with the exercise and enjoyment of public rights, including the right to use public property.
Maintaining a public nuisance is a Class C offense. At the discretion of the Court, such offenders may be required to remove or correct any property posing as a danger to public safety.

A person shall be guilty of malicious mischief if that person maliciously disturbs, defaces, injures, or destroys any tangible or personal property, including, but not limited to domestic animals, or vandalizes any property not belonging to that person.
Malicious mischief is a Class B offense. At the discretion of the Court, such offenders may be required to pay restitution for damages to the victim.

A person shall be guilty of malicious prosecution if that person maliciously procures or attempts to cause a criminal charge to be brought and prosecuted against an innocent person, knowing him/her to be innocent.
Malicious prosecution is a Class B offense.
A person is guilty of mayhem if he/she unlawfully and purposely or knowingly;
Deprives a human being of a bodily member or disables or renders it useless; or
Cuts out or disables the tongue, puts out an eye, or slits the nose, ear or lip of another.
Mayhem is a Class A offense.

section.heading: Negligent Use of a Deadly Weapon.

para.text: A person shall be guilty of negligent use of a deadly weapon if that person:
Discharges a firearm into any building or vehicle so as to knowingly endanger a person or his/her property;
Carrying a firearm while under the influence of an intoxicant or narcotic;
Endangering the safety of another by handling or using a firearm or other deadly weapon in a negligent manner; or
Discharging a firearm within one hundred (100) yards of a dwelling, building or residential area.
Negligent use of a deadly weapon is a Class B offense. Exempt from this section are law enforcement officers in the lawful discharge of their duties.

section.heading: Obstruction of Reporting or Investigation of Child Abuse or Neglect.

para.text: A person shall be guilty of obstruction of reporting or investigation of child abuse or neglect if that person knowingly obstructs, prevents, delays, interferes, or intimidates another from reporting child abuse or neglect; or denies access to a law enforcement officer or child protective services social worker in the investigation of a report of child or sexual abuse.
Obstruction of reporting or investigation of child abuse or neglect is a Class B offense.
A person shall be guilty of patronizing a prostitute if that person knowingly hires or offers to hire a prostitute to engage in a sexual act for hire with that person or another.
Patronizing prostitution is a Class C offense.

A person shall be guilty of perjury if that person makes a false statement under oath or affirmation, material to the issue or matter involved in the course of any judicial, administrative, legislative, or other official proceeding, knowing such statement to be untrue.
Perjury is a Class A offense.

A person shall be guilty of polluting waters if that person knowingly and unlawfully introduces any object or substance into any body of public water causing it to be offensive or dangerous for human or animal consumption or use.
Polluting waters is a Class A offense.

A person shall be guilty of possession of a controlled substance if that person intentionally possesses a controlled substance as defined under the Federal Controlled Substances Act, 21 § U.S.C. 801, et seq., unless the substance was obtained pursuant to a valid prescription of a medical practitioner while acting in the course of his or her professional practice.

Possession of marijuana, cannabis concentrates, cannabis extracts, or cannabis-derived products is governed by §Section 4.04.660 of this Criminal Code. A person shall not be guilty of possession of marijuana for engaging in activities authorized and in conformity with a medical cannabis program duly enacted by the Pueblo of Picuris.

Possession of a controlled substance is a Class A offense. The Court may order habitual offenders to be committed for inpatient treatment for substance abuse with any available substance abuse treatment program. Nothing in this section shall be construed as including or applying to peyote or other natural occurring herbs used or possessed for religious purposes by a member of a Native American Church or by any Native American in the practice of his or her religion.

section.heading: Possession of Alcoholic Beverages by a Person Under 21 Years of Age.

para.text: A person shall be guilty of possession of alcoholic beverages by a person under 21 years of age if that person being under 21 years of age shall:
Possess or consume any beer, wine, ale, whiskey or any alcoholic beverage;
Misrepresents his/her age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining any alcoholic beverage; or
Appear in any public or private place while under the influence of an intoxicating beverage to any degree.
Possession of alcoholic beverage by a person under 21 years of age is a Class B offense. The Court, may order habitual offenders to be committed for in-patient treatment for alcohol abuse.

A person shall be guilty of possession of marijuana if that person possesses, plants, cultivates, manufactures, distributes, sells, trades, or gives away marijuana, cannabis concentrates, cannabis extracts, or cannabis-derived products in an amount exceeding 23 total units, where a unit is equivalent to one gram of dried usable cannabis plant material or 200 milligrams of THC for cannabis-derived products.

A person shall be guilty of possession of marijuana if that person distributes, sells, trades, or gives away marijuana, cannabis concentrates, cannabis extracts, or cannabis-derived products in any amount to a person under eighteen (18) years of age.
A person shall not be guilty of possession of marijuana for engaging in activities authorized and in conformity with a medical cannabis program duly enacted by the Pueblo of Picuris.
Possession of Marijuana is a Class B offense. The Court may order habitual offenders to be committed for inpatient treatment for substance abuse with any available substance abuse treatment program.

A person shall be guilty of prostitution if that person knowingly engages in or offers to engage in a sexual act for hire. The sexual act means sexual intercourse, cunnilingus, fellatio, masturbation of another, and intercourse or the causing of penetration to any extent and with any object of the genital or anal opening of another person, whether or not there is any emission.
Prostitution is a Class B offense.

A person shall be guilty of public affray if such person voluntarily or by agreement engages in any fight with another or uses any blows or violence toward another in an angry or quarrelsome manner in any public place, to the disturbance of others.
Public affray is a Class B offense.

A person shall be guilty of public intoxication if that person is found in any public place while under the influence of intoxicating liquor, narcotics, or any other drug to the degree that he/she may endanger him/herself or other persons or property; or annoy persons in his/her vicinity.

Public intoxication is a Class B offense. The Court, in its discretion, shall order habitual offenders to be committed for in-patient treatment for alcohol and/or substance abuse with any available alcoholic or drug abuse treatment program.

A person shall be guilty of receiving stolen property if that person intentionally receives, retains, or disposes of stolen property knowing that it has been stolen or believing that it has been stolen, unless the property is received, retained, or disposed of with the intent to restore it to the owner. The requisite knowledge or belief that property has been stolen is presumed in the case of a dealer who:
Is found in possession or control of property stolen from two or more persons on two (2) separate occasions;

Acquires stolen property for a consideration which the dealer knows is far below the property's reasonable value. A dealer shall be presumed to know the fair market value of the property in which he/she deals; or
Is found in possession or control of items or property stolen within one (1) year prior to the time of the incident charged pursuant to this section.
Receiving stolen property is a Class A offense.

section.heading: Refusal to Take an Oath or Affirmation.

para.text: A person shall be guilty of refusal to take an oath or affirmation if that person refuses, when legally called upon, to give testimony before any Court, administrative proceeding, legislative proceeding or other authority in the Pueblo of Picuris, authorized to administer oaths or affirmations.
Refusal to take an oath or affirmation is a Class C offense.

A person shall be guilty of refusing to aid an officer if that person refuses, without sufficient cause, to help a law enforcement officer in the preservation of peace when called upon by such an officer.
Refusing to aid an officer is a Class B offense.

section.heading: Resisting, Evading or Obstructing an Officer.

para.text: A person shall be guilty of resisting, evading, or obstructing an officer if that person:

Knowingly obstructs, resists or opposes any law enforcement officer or any other duly authorized person serving or attempting to serve or execute any process, any rule, order of any Court or any other judicial writ or process;

Intentionally flees, attempts to evade or evading a law enforcement officer when the person committing the act of fleeing, attempting to evade or evasion has knowledge that the officer is attempting to apprehend or arrest him/her;

Willfully refuses to bring a vehicle to a stop when given a visual or audible signal to stop, whether by hand, voice, emergency light, flashing light, siren or other signal by a uniformed officer in an appropriately marked police vehicle; or
Resisting or abusing any Judge or law enforcement officer in the lawful discharge of his/her duties.
Resisting, evading or obstructing an officer is a Class B offense.
A person shall be guilty of robbery if that person takes anything of value from the person of another or from the immediate control of another, by use or threatened use of force or violence.
Robbery is a Class A offense.

section.heading: Shooting at a Dwelling or Occupied Building: at or from a Motor Vehicle.

para.text: A person shall be guilty of shooting at a dwelling or occupied building if that person:
Willfully discharges a firearm at a dwelling or occupied building; or
Is shooting at or from a motor vehicle; or
Willfully discharges a firearm at or from a motor vehicle with reckless disregard for the person of another.

Shooting at a dwelling or occupied building, at or from a motor vehicle is a Class A offense. This section shall not apply to a law enforcement officer discharging a firearm in the lawful performance of his/her duties.
A person shall be guilty of shoplifting if that person willfully:
Takes possession of any merchandise with the intent of converting it without paying for it;
Conceals any merchandise with the intent of converting it without paying for it;
Alters any label, price tag, or marking upon any merchandise with the intent of depriving the merchant of all or some part of the value of it; or
Transfers any merchandise from the container in or on which it is displayed to any other container with the intent of depriving the merchant of all or some part of the value of it.
Shoplifting is a Class C offense. The Court may order such offender to pay restitution to the merchant.
Stalking consists of:
A person knowingly pursuing a pattern of conduct that would cause a reasonable person to feel frightened, intimidated, or threatened; or
The alleged stalker must intend to place another person in reasonable apprehension of death, bodily harm, sexual assault, confinement or restraint; or
The alleged stalker must intend to cause a reasonable person to fear for his/her safety or the safety of a household member;
In furtherance of the stalking, the alleged stalker must commit one or more of the following acts on more than one occasion;
Following a person, in a place other than the residence of the alleged stalker;

Placing a person under surveillance by remaining present outside that person's school, residence, workplace, or vehicle or any other place frequented by the person, other than the residence of the alleged stalker; or
Harassing a person.
Stalking is a Class B offense.

As used in this section, "household member" means a spouse, former spouse, family member, including a relative, parent, present or former step-parent, present or former in-law, child or co-parent of a child, or a person with whom the victim has had a continuing personal relationship.

In addition to any punishment provided pursuant to the provisions of this section, the Court shall order a person convicted of stalking to participate in and complete a program of professional counseling at his/her own expense.
A person is guilty of tampering with evidence if, believing that an official proceeding or investigation is pending or about to be instituted, he/she:
Alters, destroys conceals or removes any record, document, or thing with purpose to impair its verity or availability in such proceeding or investigation; or
Makes, presents or uses any record, document, or thing knowing it to be false and with a purpose to mislead a public servant who is or may be engaged in such proceeding or investigation.
Tampering with evidence is a Class B offense.
A person is guilty of tampering with public records if he/she:

Knowingly makes a false entry in, or false alteration of, any record, document or thing belonging to or received or kept by, the Tribe or government for information or record, or required by law to be kept by others for information of the Tribe or government; or
Makes, presents or uses any record, document, or thing knowing it to be false, and with purpose that it be taken as a genuine part of information of records referred to in Subsection A(1) above; or
Purposely and unlawfully destroys, conceals, removes or otherwise impairs the verity or availability of any such record, document or thing.
Tampering with public records is a Class B offense.
A person is guilty of tampering with witnesses if:
Believing that an official proceeding or investigation is pending or about to be instituted, he/she attempts to induce or otherwise cause a person to:
Testify or inform falsely; or
Withhold any testimony, information, document or thing; or
Elude legal process summoning him/her to testify or supply evidence; or
Absent him/herself from any proceeding or investigation to which he/she has been legally summoned.
He/she harms another by an unlawful act in retaliation for anything done by another in his/her capacity as a witness or informant; or
He/she solicits, accepts or agrees to accept any benefit in consideration of his/her doing any of the things specified in this section.
Tampering with witnesses is a Class A offense if the actor employs force, deception, threat or offer of a valuable benefit; otherwise, tampering with witnesses is a Class B offense.

A person is guilty of terroristic threats if he/she threatens verbally or in writing to commit any offense involving violence with intent to terrorize another or place such other in fear of imminent serious bodily injury or to cause evacuation of a building, place of assembly, or place of public transportation, or otherwise to cause serious public inconvenience, or in reckless disregard of the risk of causing such terror or inconvenience.
Terroristic Threats is a Class A offense.

A person shall be guilty of trafficking in a controlled substance if that person manufactures, distributes, sells, trades, gives away, or possesses with intent to distribute intent to distribute any controlled substance as defined under the Federal Controlled Substances Act, 21 § U.S.C. 801, et seq., without a valid license.

Planting, cultivating, manufacturing, distributing, selling, trading, or giving away marijuana, cannabis concentrates, cannabis extracts, or cannabis-derived products is governed by §Section 4.04.660 of this Criminal Code. A person shall not be guilty of possession of marijuana for engaging in activities authorized and in conformity with a medical cannabis program duly enacted by the Pueblo of Picuris.

Trafficking in a controlled substance is a Class A offense. Nothing in this section shall be construed as including or applying to peyote or other natural occurring herbs manufactured, distributed, sold, traded, given away, or possessed with intent to distribute for religious purposes by a member of a Native American Church or by any Native American in the practice of his or her religion.

section.heading: Unauthorized Graffiti on Personal or Real Property.

para.text: A person shall be guilty of unauthorized graffiti on personal or real property if that person intentionally and maliciously defaces any personal or real property of another with graffiti or other inscribed material inscribed with ink, paint, spray paint, crayon, charcoal or the use of any object without the consent of the owner of such property.

Unauthorized graffiti on personal or real property is a Class B offense. At the discretion of the Court, such offenders may be required to pay restitution for damages to the victim and/or restore the property to its original state.

A person shall be guilty of unlawful assembly if such person assembles with two (2) or more person and disturbs the peace by using force or violence; or threatens to cause such disturbance using force or violence against the person or property of another and who shall make any overt act to carry out such unlawful purpose
Unlawful assembly is a Class B offense.

A person shall be guilty of an unlawful bomb scare if such person knowingly makes a bomb scare consisting of falsely and maliciously stating to another that a bomb or other explosive has been placed in such a position that property or persons are likely to be injured or destroyed.
Unlawful bomb scare is a Class A offense.

section.heading: Unlawful Carrying of a Deadly Weapon.

para.text: A person shall be guilty of unlawful carrying of a deadly weapon if that person carries a concealed loaded firearm or any type of deadly weapon on his/her person or in close proximity thereto, so that the weapon is readily accessible for use.
Unlawful carrying of a deadly weapon is a Class B offense. Any person authorized by the Pueblo, State, or Federal Governments to carry a firearm shall be exempt from this section.

section.heading: Unlawful Carrying of a Firearm in Licensed Liquor Establishment.

para.text: A person shall be guilty of unlawful carrying of a firearm in a licensed liquor establishment if that person carries a loaded or unloaded firearm on any premises licensed by the Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control for the dispensing of alcoholic beverages.

Unlawful carrying of a firearm in a licensed liquor establishment is a Class B offense. Exempt from this section are law enforcement officers in the lawful discharge of their duties; the owner or operator of the license premises or their agents, including privately employed security personnel during the performance of their duties; or by a person on the area of licensed premises, primarily utilized for vehicular traffic or parking.

A person shall be guilty of unlawful possession of a switchblade if that person has possession of any knife which has a blade which opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring or other device in the handle of the knife, or any knife having a blade which opens or falls or is ejected into position by the force of gravity or by any outward thrust or movement from the center.
Unlawful possession of switchblades is a Class C offense.
A person shall be guilty of unlawful use of a telephone if such person with the intent to terrify, intimidate, threaten, harass, annoy, or offend, to telephone another person and:
Uses obscene, lewd, or profane language;
Suggests any lewd, criminal, or sexual overtures;
Threatens to inflict injury or physical harm to the person or property of another;
Attempts to extort money or any other thing of value from such person;
Disturbs by repeated anonymous telephone calls the peace, quiet, or right of privacy of any other person at the place where the telephone call or calls were received;
Maliciously makes a telephone call, whether or not a conversation ensues, with the intent to annoy or disturb another; or
Disrupts the telecommunications of another.
Unlawful use of a telephone is a Class C offense.

section.heading: Unlawfully Permitting Livestock upon Public Highways.

para.text: A person shall be guilty of unlawfully permitting livestock upon public highways if that person, as an owner or custodian of livestock, negligently permits his/her livestock to run at large upon any part of a public highway which is fenced on both sides.
Unlawfully permitting livestock upon public highways is a Class C offense.

A person is guilty of vehicular homicide if, while under the influence of an alcoholic beverage, intoxicating liquor, a controlled substance, or any drug, to a degree which renders the person incapable of safely driving a vehicle, he/she causes the death of another by operating a motor vehicle in a reckless, negligent, or careless manner.

Any chemical test administered on a defendant with his/her consent or after his/her arrest, whether with or against his/her consent, to determine blood alcohol content, shall be admissible in accordance with the rules of evidence.
Any presumptions established to determine intoxication based on blood alcohol content shall apply to the proof of intoxication under this section.
For purpose of this section, a motor vehicle is any self-propelled vehicle and includes, but is not limited to any automobile, truck, van, motorcycle, all-terrain vehicle, tractor or snowmobile.
Vehicular homicide is a Class A offense.
A person shall be guilty of a weapons offense if:
Being addicted to any narcotic drug, or having been declared mentally incompetent, he/she owns or has in his/her possession or under his/her custody or control a dangerous weapon; or

Being intoxicated or otherwise under the influence of alcoholic beverages or other intoxicating substance, drug, or medicine, he/she has a dangerous weapon in his/her possession or under his/her custody or control; or
He/she carries a loaded firearm in a vehicle on a public road without lawful authority to do so; or
He/she has on his/her person a dangerous weapon with the intent to unlawfully assault another; or
He/she discharges any kind of firearm from a motor vehicle or within a village or posted "no shooting" recreation area without lawful authority to do so; or
He/she discharges a firearm from, upon or across any public highway without lawful authority to do so; or
Being under the age of sixteen (16) years old, he/she possesses a firearm without the consent of his/her parent or guardian.
Definition:

"Dangerous weapon" means any item that in the manner of its use or intended use is capable of causing death or serious bodily injury. In determining whether an item, object or thing not commonly known as a dangerous weapon is a dangerous weapon, the character of the instrument, object or thing, the character of the wound produced, and the manner in which the instrument, item or thing was used shall be determinative.
"Firearms" means pistols, revolvers, rifles, shotguns, and any device that is capable of being used as a weapon because it expels a projectile by some means of force.

A firearm or other weapon shall be deemed loaded when there is an unexpended cartridge, shell or projectile in the firing position, except in the case of pistols and revolvers, in which case they shall be deemed loaded with the unexpended cartridge, shell or projectile is in a position that the manual operation of any mechanism would cause the unexpended cartridge, shell or projectile to be fired.
Weapons offense is a Class B offense.
